quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I created a career growth framework for product managers, which comprises of three things. What you produce, what you bring to the table, and what's your operating model.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Offers a simple three-part framework PMs can use to assess and improve their career growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Your advice is early in your career, focus on just getting stuff out and done.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an execution-first priority that can accelerate early-career learning and credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Can you show me your last PRD? Can you show me the last product note that you sent? Can you show me the product strategy doc? You must have that impact through the artifacts that you work on.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Emphasizes that measurable PM impact is often visible through concrete written artifacts, not just meetings or ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: How you view change, whether you are focusing on things you control, and third is how you see yourself. The moment you are able to correct those stories, you may be back on the growth path again.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Identifies internal narratives and locus of control as key blockers to growth—and a lever to restart progress.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We all know that your website shouldn't be a static asset, it should be a dynamic part of your strategy that drives conversions.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Webflow)
quotes.context: A practical mental model for treating the website as an ongoing growth lever rather than a one-time deliverable.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But here's a number for you. 54% of leaders say web updates take too long, that's over half of you listening right now.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Webflow)
quotes.context: A concrete data point highlighting how speed of iteration on web experiences is a widespread bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Uizard, I can simply upload my screenshot and Uizard's AI will turn them into a fully editable UI design that I can then take, make tweaks to, and then share with my teams in minutes.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Uizard)
quotes.context: An actionable workflow for turning feedback artifacts into editable designs quickly to accelerate iteration cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Developers can even export UI components to React and CSS to speed up their development.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Uizard)
quotes.context: A specific example of reducing handoff friction by moving from design directly into implementation artifacts.

quotes.topic_title: Why Vikrama is known for talent building
quotes.text: I'm on this quest to meet the most insightful product leaders from all over the world and your name has come up more times than almost any other product person when I ask people for their favorite product leaders in Asia.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights Vikrama’s unusually strong reputation via repeated third-party endorsements, signaling credibility in talent building.

quotes.topic_title: Why Vikrama is known for talent building
quotes.text: And you're also the third guest from Gojek, so there's definitely something in the water over there and I want to talk about that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Points to a potential organizational talent system at Gojek worth investigating as a replicable model.

quotes.topic_title: Why Vikrama is known for talent building
quotes.text: To just dive right in, you have a very strong reputation for building incredibly strong product talent and also design talent, and also helping people transition from other roles into product management, which a lot of people listening to this podcast dream to do.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames the segment’s core theme: developing PM/design talent and enabling role transitions into PM.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of fast-growing PMs and the 3Ws
quotes.text: When I was younger and I was starting off, I used to think it's all about the product. If you've got a really cool product to work on, your growth's guaranteed.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that career growth is primarily determined by working on high-visibility products.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of fast-growing PMs and the 3Ws
quotes.text: But as I started seeing more and more product managers at their craft, I saw that working on a cool product area is not the only thing.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Reframes PM career growth as driven by craft and behaviors beyond product “coolness.”

quotes.topic_title: Traits of fast-growing PMs and the 3Ws
quotes.text: And based on that, I created a career growth framework for product managers, which comprises of three things, and I call it three W's. So what you produce, what you bring to the table, and what's your operating model?
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable 3-part framework practitioners can use to diagnose and improve career growth.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of fast-growing PMs and the 3Ws
quotes.text: So focus on that output significantly.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for early-career PMs to prioritize concrete outputs before trying to own higher-level outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of fast-growing PMs and the 3Ws
quotes.text: As you get comfortable with output and you start getting comfortable with working with different stakeholders, you start controlling what outputs are necessary, which is when you move to the outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Provides a progression model from executing outputs to shaping outcomes as stakeholder influence and judgment grow.

quotes.topic_title: What you produce: outputs to outcomes progression
quotes.text: the very first thing that anyone, when you're starting off, produces is outputs, okay? The output can be launching a product, it can be analyzing and running an experiment, and it could even be just being a part of the team and contributing to a go-to market strategy. So focus on that output significantly.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Defines an early-career prioritization model: build credibility through concrete outputs before optimizing for impact/outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: What you produce: outputs to outcomes progression
quotes.text: The mistake that I see a lot of product managers make is they start operating in either output or outcomes. And when you are transitioning to outcomes, it's very important that you continue to still hone your craft on outputs.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Warns against a false tradeoff—advancing to outcomes/strategy shouldn’t come at the expense of execution skill.

quotes.topic_title: What you produce: outputs to outcomes progression
quotes.text: You always, always have to have the output and outcome even when you're moving up the so-called career management ladder.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb for senior PMs: keep both execution (outputs) and ownership (outcomes) in play.

quotes.topic_title: What you produce: outputs to outcomes progression
quotes.text: For instance, if you are sourcing content for your homepage, what are the different avenues that you can source content from? What is the easiest to source? What is the most difficult to source? Just ranking it all in that order goes a long way.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Concrete example of a small, high-leverage output (ranking sourcing options) that unblocks teams and feeds strategy.

quotes.topic_title: What you produce: outputs to outcomes progression
quotes.text: focus on outputs at the start of your careers and don't forget outputs even when you grow in your career.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Summarizes the progression model as a simple, actionable career guideline.

quotes.topic_title: Does product area impact matter for growth?
quotes.text: So I'll give you my example.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: He signals a concrete personal story to illustrate how impact/visibility isn’t the only driver of growth.

quotes.topic_title: Does product area impact matter for growth?
quotes.text: My product area ended up being the center and focus of the organization, yet the product manager who was chosen to lead the area when it became big wasn't me.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example: even owning the most central area didn’t guarantee being selected to lead it.

quotes.topic_title: Does product area impact matter for growth?
quotes.text: But now when I look back, I can see why that happened because that product manager was so much better at the overall craft of output, yet when they were focusing on outcome, we're not forgetting the output as well.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Highlights a mental model: outcomes matter, but strong output craft is a differentiator and shouldn’t be neglected.

quotes.topic_title: Does product area impact matter for growth?
quotes.text: So they were just better at me on launching products, they were better at me on working with design, in producing design artwork, and they were definitely better than me in running the experiments as well.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Breaks “better execution” into specific, actionable competencies (launching, design collaboration, experimentation).

quotes.topic_title: Does product area impact matter for growth?
quotes.text: Yeah, basically when you're just starting out, just execute well, execute smoothly, ship things on time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Direct early-career guidance: execution quality and reliable shipping are key differentiators.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples of strong outputs: be useful
quotes.text: Go and ask your product leader, go and ask other leaders on what are the areas they are blocked on.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable tactic for finding high-leverage work: identify where leaders are stuck and turn that into deliverables you can own.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples of strong outputs: be useful
quotes.text: You can volunteer and definitely own and deliver the first drafts of those even if the final draft is not something that you own.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A practical methodology for creating impact quickly: produce first drafts (briefs/slides/reviews) to unblock others without needing final ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples of strong outputs: be useful
quotes.text: Absolutely. And be useful in doing the small things which make an impact and also contribute to your learning versus being useful in areas which you think the mini CEO should be working on.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A counterweight to the “mini-CEO” trope: prioritize small, high-impact outputs that accelerate learning over premature strategy posturing.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples of strong outputs: be useful
quotes.text: When you're just starting out, you haven't earned the right to inform strategy and vision people. Why would people follow you at this point? We just need to get stuff done, so that comes over time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of early PM effectiveness: credibility to shape strategy is earned through execution and delivery first.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples of strong outputs: be useful
quotes.text: It's a very, very important thing for you to know that you are one part of the cog wheel, you're not the entire wheel yourself.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A mental model for operating in organizations: PMs succeed by fitting into the system and collaborating, not by acting as the sole driver.

quotes.topic_title: What you bring: artifacts and impact-on-impact
quotes.text: Number two is what you bring to the table. Now, I think how I describe that is what is your impact on impact? So the first access is impact, but you also need to have an impact on impact.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable framework for career growth: not just outcomes, but proving your personal contribution to those outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: What you bring: artifacts and impact-on-impact
quotes.text: And this is what I had missed a lot in my early career, that you put the coolest product areas, your product area is successful and that automatically guarantees your growth. It doesn't. You have to also show that yes, you were a useful contributor to having that particular impact.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that being on a winning team isn’t enough—you must make your contribution legible.

quotes.topic_title: What you bring: artifacts and impact-on-impact
quotes.text: You have to have to be able to produce these artifacts which are product artifacts.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Actionable advice that PMs should personally own core artifacts (not outsource them) to demonstrate competence and progression.

quotes.topic_title: What you bring: artifacts and impact-on-impact
quotes.text: There are three tenets that I define in working well as a product manager with others. Number one is raise difficult issues without being difficult to work with. Bring out important topics without drawing importance to yourself. And finally, you are in charge of getting the decisions made and not making all the decisions yourself.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A practical operating-model framework for stakeholder management that’s easy to remember and apply day-to-day.

quotes.topic_title: Operating model: stakeholder collaboration and decision-making
quotes.text: There are three tenets that I define in working well as a product manager with others. Number one is raise difficult issues without being difficult to work with. Bring out important topics without drawing importance to yourself. And finally, you are in charge of getting the decisions made and not making all the decisions yourself.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A concise, repeatable 3-part operating model for cross-functional collaboration and decision-making as a PM.

quotes.topic_title: Operating model: stakeholder collaboration and decision-making
quotes.text: These three tenets are easy to say, but they become very, very hard to embody and display on a day-to-day basis.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Highlights that the real challenge is consistent execution of the principles, not understanding them intellectually.

quotes.topic_title: Operating model: stakeholder collaboration and decision-making
quotes.text: So the three things which are very important for product managers to work with others and other stakeholders are raise difficult issues without being difficult to work with, bring out important topics without drawing importance to yourself, and be able to get decisions made without having to make all the decisions yourself.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A mantra-like restatement that’s easy to recall and use as a self-check in stakeholder interactions.

quotes.topic_title: Operating model: stakeholder collaboration and decision-making
quotes.text: It's always within your control and it's always the things that are within your control that you should be controlling rather than focusing on the things that are not within your control and obsessing about those.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A practical focus principle for PMs to prioritize influence and action over unproductive frustration.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back effectively without friction
quotes.text: It's always within your control and it's always the things that are within your control that you should be controlling rather than focusing on the things that are not within your control and obsessing about those.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A practical prioritization lens for where to spend energy when navigating disagreements and ambiguity.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back effectively without friction
quotes.text: It's not just about the spread and the width of the things that you're doing, but it's also about the depth of those things as well.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A memorable quality bar for PM output that reframes “doing many things” into “doing fewer things deeply.”

quotes.topic_title: How to push back effectively without friction
quotes.text: Some product managers, what they bring to the table is arguments, what they bring to the table are debates, what they bring to the table are pushbacks, while others are able to channelize the questions, channelize the inputs, channelize the direction and convert that into strategic choices which can then shape discussions, which can then shape direction. Be the latter and you will rise faster in your career.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career-growth model: convert conflict into strategic choices rather than “winning” debates.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back effectively without friction
quotes.text: Just don't be someone who's seen as an obstacle and a hindrance and as someone who's just very difficult to work with, but rather see as someone who's able to actually add value to whatever your leader, your stakeholders, your product area demands and you are able to advance the product and the direction and execution forward.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A clear intent-setting guideline for pushback: optimize for forward progress and value-add, not resistance.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back effectively without friction
quotes.text: What I've seen that people who do pushback very successfully and are still considered not difficult to work with, they are also able to bring the tempo of the conversation to a more logical space from an emotional space.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A concrete pushback technique: de-escalate emotion and reset the discussion on logical, equal footing.

quotes.topic_title: Why careers stall: control, change, and self-stories
quotes.text: So the first thing is whether you are focusing on things you control or whether you're focusing on things that are beyond your control. Second, what's your relationship with change? And third is how you see yourself. The third is very, very powerful and we'll talk about that as well.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A crisp 3-part diagnostic framework for why career growth stalls: control, change, and self-identity.

quotes.topic_title: Why careers stall: control, change, and self-stories
quotes.text: As you start becoming mid-senior, I see the conversation shifts from what can I do, how am I learning, how am I growing, to why is the organization not doing this for me? Why can that stakeholder not change this thing about themselves? Why do I not get to work on projects like this? Things which start going outside your control. And it is very, very important that you keep your focus no matter what stage of career you get into what you can control.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Highlights a common mid-senior trap—blaming externalities—and gives a practical focus reset toward controllables.

quotes.topic_title: Why careers stall: control, change, and self-stories
quotes.text: So it's very important that as you get to mid-senior level, you are constantly checking on what you can do to keep increasing your rate of change.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A simple operating principle: treat “rate of change” (skill growth velocity) as the leading indicator for career growth.

quotes.topic_title: Why careers stall: control, change, and self-stories
quotes.text: One of the simplest things that you can do is if you think you are four on data, figure out who. And you may be four on data out of five in data. Within your organization, start benchmarking yourself with the best in the industry. You'll automatically see that your scale drops and as your scale drops, you start seeing what you need to improve and do.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A concrete method to reignite growth: recalibrate self-assessment by benchmarking beyond your company to expose new gaps.

quotes.topic_title: Why careers stall: control, change, and self-stories
quotes.text: But then I started understanding these things are not just signaling, they are also anti-signaling.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that identity labels (e.g., “high agency,” “collaborative”) can become excuses that justify bad tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Vikrama’s recalibration at Gojek and mindful agency
quotes.text: And it auto-calibrated me in my eyes on where it was, but that also created a hunger in me that this is what I need to fix.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A practical reframe: exposure to stronger peers can reset self-assessment and convert insecurity into a concrete improvement drive.

quotes.topic_title: Vikrama’s recalibration at Gojek and mindful agency
quotes.text: And I also found that seeing yourself as someone who's a learner is an enabling story to tell yourself, okay?
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A memorable identity-level mental model: adopting a “learner” self-story makes growth feel possible and sustainable.

quotes.topic_title: Vikrama’s recalibration at Gojek and mindful agency
quotes.text: It may not be the most exciting story, it may not be the most memorable story about yourself, but it is definitely one of the enabling stories as well.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Counterintuitive point that the most useful self-narratives aren’t the flashiest—they’re the ones that enable consistent progress.

quotes.topic_title: Vikrama’s recalibration at Gojek and mindful agency
quotes.text: But as I started working more in Southeast Asia, I learned that mindfulness is also very, very important, that not every team, not every culture will work with you in a very hyper aggressive style.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Actionable cross-cultural lesson: effectiveness requires adapting agency/communication style to the team and cultural context.

quotes.topic_title: Vikrama’s recalibration at Gojek and mindful agency
quotes.text: And I'm still learning on that and therefore, I've started using a word, I don't want to be a high agency person, I want to be a mindful agency person.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A novel reframing of “high agency” into “mindful agency” as a guiding principle for getting outcomes without cultural friction.

quotes.topic_title: Using feedback without overwhelm: pick leverage areas
quotes.text: You need to channelize feedback into okay, is this an area that you are targeting for growth or not?
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A practical filter for turning broad stakeholder feedback into focused growth priorities across defined skill axes.

quotes.topic_title: Using feedback without overwhelm: pick leverage areas
quotes.text: You can't improve on every single area. That's what overwhelms you. You need to pick which is the area which is the maximum leverage for you and improve on that particular aspect and then move on to the next area, then move on to the next area and so on.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A high-leverage, one-at-a-time improvement strategy to avoid overwhelm while still making consistent progress.

quotes.topic_title: Using feedback without overwhelm: pick leverage areas
quotes.text: Obviously, if you are floundering in something, if you're really negative in something, then you fix that first because that will give you the highest leverage.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A prioritization rule: address the biggest weakness first because it unlocks disproportionate gains.

quotes.topic_title: Using feedback without overwhelm: pick leverage areas
quotes.text: For skills which are softer in nature like communication and collaboration and community, those are skills that you will work on all your life. You'll never achieve anywhere near two or five on five on those ever.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that “soft skills” are never finished—plan for continuous iteration rather than mastery.

quotes.topic_title: Using feedback without overwhelm: pick leverage areas
quotes.text: My advice is if you're coming from design and research background, then you pick data or tech. If you're coming from a data or tech background, then you pick design and research, and that gives you the maximum leverage because that's a skill that you will necessarily not have developed over the years.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A concrete skill-pairing heuristic: complement your background by building the adjacent discipline for maximum career leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Transitioning into PM: tailoring growth plans by background
quotes.text: For instance, we recently had two PMs, one who came from a growth background. This is actually [inaudible 00:42:24]'s team. And one from a research background. And with both of them, we use very different tactics.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Highlights the core methodology: tailor PM transition plans based on a person’s prior functional background rather than using a one-size-fits-all approach.

quotes.topic_title: Transitioning into PM: tailoring growth plans by background
quotes.text: So we gave one of finding driver redesign, which was very much a very design-focused product, but we still had them leverage their data skills because we were able to create a PRD with incredible amount of data on exactly what different segments of customers we're doing.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Concrete example of assigning a “stretch” project (design-heavy) while still leveraging the transferee’s strength (data) to accelerate growth.

quotes.topic_title: Transitioning into PM: tailoring growth plans by background
quotes.text: Similarly, the PM who transitioned from research, I kept giving feedback on technology and data skills are the ones that we need to check. And I need to hear from engineers that yes, they're able to work with her very strongly.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Actionable coaching tactic: define missing-skill checkpoints and validate progress via partner-team (engineering) feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Transitioning into PM: tailoring growth plans by background
quotes.text: The only watch-out is that it doesn't work out always. In some cases, some PMs will pick these things up fast, and it also makes a big difference if you are transitioning when you are slightly younger in your career.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Counterbalance to the framework: transition speed and success vary, and career stage meaningfully affects ramp time.

quotes.topic_title: Transitioning into PM: tailoring growth plans by background
quotes.text: So it's sometimes okay to go a little slow when you're transitioning so that you're able to go faster later rather than getting faster somewhere and then being stuck there for a while.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Memorable principle for skill transitions: prioritize foundational ramp over short-term speed to avoid long-term plateaus.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Coda every day to help me plan each episode of this very podcast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete example of using a single tool as the operational hub for a repeatable planning workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's where I keep my content calendar, my guest research, and also the questions that I plan to ask each guest.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable breakdown of what to centralize to make planning and execution smoother.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Coda, you can stay aligned and ship faster by managing your planning cycles in one location.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Clear operational principle: consolidate planning cycles to improve alignment and delivery speed.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can set and measure OKRs with full visibility across teams and stakeholders.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Practical guidance on making goal-setting measurable and transparent across an organization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can map dependencies, create progress visualizations, and identify risk areas.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Tactical checklist of planning mechanics that help teams anticipate blockers and manage execution risk.

quotes.topic_title: What is a PM: ambiguity, art vs science, glue role
quotes.text: And my general answer to that is, if this is something which is blocking the progress on the product, then yes, the product manager should work on that.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for clarifying PM scope amid ambiguity: unblock product progress.

quotes.topic_title: What is a PM: ambiguity, art vs science, glue role
quotes.text: So you have to understand there's an art to it and there's a science to it, but you can use the science to figure out the art.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for PM skill-building: apply frameworks and rigor to develop judgment and craft.

quotes.topic_title: What is a PM: ambiguity, art vs science, glue role
quotes.text: The second side of it is what we spoke about earlier that instead of figuring out what is product management, figure out what's your contribution, what's your output and figure out are you contributing on these access on data, on design, on technology and on strategy.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Reframes the role-definition problem into an output-and-contribution lens across four core axes.

quotes.topic_title: What is a PM: ambiguity, art vs science, glue role
quotes.text: So it's not about you standing alone, it's you always collaborating and pairing with someone else. But you are the only one who's pairing with everyone else and therefore, you have that unique insight which no one else in the team will have.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Defines PM as a “connector” role whose leverage comes from cross-functional pairing and synthesis.

quotes.topic_title: What is a PM: ambiguity, art vs science, glue role
quotes.text: You see yourself as playing a role and not your title and not your function, and that just clarifies a lot of things for people.
quotes.speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
quotes.context: Counteracts title-based confusion by focusing on the role you’re playing in a given team and context.
